bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, January 15, 1930

div1.p: Carter is eager to see the completion of the final editing of the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever and explains that her sole focus is the publication of the book.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, January 15, 1930
div1.opener:
Book. Bibliography
Frost.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
January 15, 1930.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
Thank you and Miss Frederick very much for “rounding up” Lizana
and San Buenaventura for me. I am sorry to have left them in Baltimore,
but I was suffering while there with a dying nerve in one of my teeth.
This made attention to detail difficult.

Up, to last Monday, when she had to leave town, Miss Brown and I
haved been working hard, both separately and together, on the additional
investigation you wished made on the list of bibliographic references
you gave me in Baltimore. Will try to send over what we have already
found tomorrow and other things as we clear them up. [unclear]We are trying
to do this as quickly as possible, in the hope that the fractional equi-
valent for the “seven consecutive days,” which you felt would be suffi-
cient to complete the final editing, may materialize more quickly then
we dared hope when last I saw you.

In the interim--oh! Friend of my Father!--there is as much chance
of my “forgetting about the book and taking up other interests” as there
would be of you and “big Susan” following a similar proceedure had “lit-
tle Susan” (which the Lord forbid!) had to be consigned to the care of
the best surgeon on earth for some operation essential to her future ex-
istence. You might, as have I! the most perfect and entire confidence in
your man, but until the thing was done, I think that you would find it
as hard as I to live for anything beyond his “pronunciamento” that all
at last was “well.”with the child”.

When you have a half hour to spare, I should be glad to take over
some books (re the date of the beginnings of the wanderings of the Chi-
chemecs: Sec. iii. p. i. page 12, as I do not see how we can let the ref.
to the Anales de Chimalpahin stand). These books also have some maps I
am sure you would like to see. By the way Herrera gives “R. de cempoal”
as north of Vera Cruz, as does Joyce, an eminent modern authority (See
Ency. Brit, 1929) gives “Cempoala” about 15 miles north of Vera Cruz, on
the coast. Clavigero, however, in his old map of the Mexican Empire gives
“Chempoalla,” to the south of Vera Crux: also about 15 miles.
Salve!
